instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
Hello

Liquid damaged board, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, 2015. There was a bit of corrosion around <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> chip (<CHIP>U8020</CHIP>) but I cleaned up the area and its working.  I tossed it in the ultrasonic to rule out any hidden corrosion.

Charger is taking 29mA and not turning on.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>= 8.56V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>=3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>=5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>=0V

I have not found any shorts on any of the main power rails. I replaced clock chip, reflowed SMC, then replaced SMC. No change.

Bad CPU? Where do I go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
Put the board in UC after seeing TINY corroded area?
Why the people expect always miracles from UC?

Check for knocked off components, or broken traces.
Hot spots in UC can cause such problems.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
I put the board in the ultrasonic cleaner after my "cleanup" attempts were not successful. I figured there may be something hidden. There are a couple of corroded test points, one being <SIGNAL>PCH_I1C1_SDA</SIGNAL>, but it seems to be still connected through the board.

I have scoured the board for broken traces and knocked off components with no luck.

Triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and checked for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>. It drops to .358V and holds steady, then goes back to 3.42 when I release trigger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.

You've said the board was working, after cleaning <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> area.
Why did you insist to put in UC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
I apologize. I was trying to say that <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> line, and <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> was working, and stable. The board, however...was not powering up.

No pulse at  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  while triggering SMC ONOFF.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  is 0V. I checked <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is getting 2.97V, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is getting 3.3V. <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR> is good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is lower than normal.
May be under <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> threshold input, not sure.
Still problem with <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> and S5 missing
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>. Board fired right up. Looks like <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> needs more than 2.97V.

Thanks!
